journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Volumetric error modeling and compensation considering thermal effect on five-axis machine tools

contrib-group.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, China

author-notes.corresp: Yi Zhang, School of Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China. Email: zhangyitop@gmail.com

abstract.p: This article intends to provide an error compensation system for five-axis machine tools. A volumetric error model is established with homogeneous transformation matrix method, from which compensation values of both orientation and position errors can be obtained. Thirty-seven errors on a five-axis machine tool are classified into three categories – functional, random, and negligible errors, among which the effect of the first one on volumetric accuracy is considered as great enough to be included in this model. Some typical modeling methods are discussed on positioning and straightness errors, considering both geometric and thermal effects. Then, we propose a compensation implementation technique based on the function of external machine zero point shift and Ethernet data communication protocol for machine tools. Finally, laser diagonal measurements have been conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed volumetric error compensation system.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Five-axis machine tools are becoming increasingly popular and can be found in a large number of manufacturing applications, from automotive to aerospace, large mechanical parts to miniature medical equipment, daily repair tools to scientific research instruments, as they can provide better tool orientation ability, higher material removal rate, less fixture and tool adjusting time, and lower production cost. However, five-axis machine tools are usually more complicated and less rigid in structure compared with three-axis machine tools, which leads to lower machining accuracy.1 Here, geometric and thermal errors are the dominant factors. Thermal deformation, especially, has been investigated to account for 70% of the total errors.2,3 Therefore, this research concentrates on the volumetric error affected by both geometric and thermal effects and proposes a synthesized model for volumetric error compensation on five-axis machine tools.

During the past decades, considerable researches were conducted to investigate the measurement, identification, and compensation of errors inherent to machine tools.4,5 Compared with 21 errors on a three-axis machine tool,6 the number of errors rises to 37 on a five-axis machine tool due to the presence of rotary axes. It is very difficult and time-consuming to identify all the errors. Also, the increasing amount of the errors directly leads to complexity of the mathematical model. In addition, the coupling relationship between translational and rotary axes make volumetric error compensation a tough task. Hsu and Wang1 proposed a decouple method, in which the orientation error was compensated first and the position error was recalculated considering the effect of rotary axes’ compensation motion. Khan and Chen7 proposed a methodology for systematic geometric error compensation on five-axis machine tools. Bohez8 introduced a method to compensate for the systematic errors based on the closed-loop volumetric error relation. Hsu9 applied the homogeneous transformation matrix (HTM) method to deduce the geometric error model for three-axis machine tools and then simplified the error model to a kinematic parameter-independent model in order to make it practical for error compensation. Zhu et al.10 developed an integrated geometric error compensation method to reduce the volumetric error by modifying NC code. All the above researches are of great significance in reducing geometric errors. However, they neglect the thermal deformation of the machine tool. So, the compensation accuracy may deteriorate with temperature change in the machining process.

Zhu et al.11 proposed a thermal error model through thermal mode concept, which was another commonly used method to study the temperature field on machine tools. Creighton et al.12 described a spindle growth compensation scheme that aimed to reduce its thermally induced machining error. Finite element analysis was also conducted on that spindle assembly. Yang and Ni13 used the dynamic neural network for the estimation of errors due to thermal loading. Zhang et al.14 proposed a thermal error modeling method based on gray neural network. Wang15 proposed a new data processing method which integrated the advantages of gray model, hierarchical genetic algorithm, and neural network so as to optimize the thermal error model of machine tools. Jiri16 proposed a decomposition method to describe the machine tool deformation in spindle axis direction and used multiple linear regression model to predict the thermal errors of different machine components. Wang et al.17 established a compound error model that considered the effect of both geometric and thermal errors, in which multiple linear regression method was used to model the relationship between temperature variables and thermal errors. However, the machine tool thermal deformation process is in fact a non-linear system. So, the compensation accuracy of the error model should be improved.

This article develops an error compensation system for five-axis machine tools considering both geometric and thermal effects. In the following section, a synthesized volumetric error model is established based on the HTM method and described in detail. According to the characteristic of error components, 37 errors are classified into three categories. Also, only the functional error components are needed to be included in the synthesized model. Some typical modeling methods for them are presented in the ‘Modeling for geometric and thermal error components’ section. Following this, a novel compensation implementation method and experimental verification study are discussed. Finally, some conclusions are drawn.

sec.title: Synthesized volumetric error modeling with HTM method
sec.p:
Five-axis machine tools generally have three translational and two rotary axes. There are 288 applicable machine configurations in the machine tool manufacturing market.18 However, all those machine tools can be classified into three main types according to different arrangements of the two rotary axes in the kinematic chain: the spindle rotating, rotary table, and hybrid type.19 In this study, a five-axis machine tool with a rotary table is considered as the research object. As shown in Figure 1, the research and experiments are both conducted on these types of machining tools. The kinematic chain of the machine is composed of a sequential arrangement of connect components. One end of the chain starts from the tool coordinate system (TCS) which is attached to the vertical spindle, and the spindle is then mounted with three translational axes. Meanwhile, the other end of the chain starts from the workpiece coordinate system (WCS), which is mounted at the rotary table controlled by two rotary axes. Then, the two parts of the kinematic chain terminate at the machine bed which is represented as the machine coordinate system (MCS). Figure 1.
Five-axis machine tool with a rotary table: (a) laser interferometer measurement and (b) temperature sensor locations.

Some other coordinate systems should be defined to establish the volumetric error model. See Figure 2; the origin of MCS is located at the intersection of A- and C-axes. The initial position of A-axis coordinate system (ACS) overlaps with the MCS. C-axis coordinate system (CCS) is defined at the center of the top surface of the rotary table. All the translational axis coordinate systems, including X-axis coordinate system (XCS), Y-axis coordinate system (YCS), and Z-axis coordinate system (ZCS), are defined co-axial to MCS. To simplify the model, the backlash errors of five axes are not considered here and they are compensated beforehand. However, geometric and thermal errors caused by the connect components in the kinematic chain are discussed in this article. Figure 2.
Coordinate systems definition of the kinematic chain.

In order to determine the volumetric error, including position and orientation errors, HTM from TCS to WCS should be first established. Let WTT be the transformation matrix, then we obtain the following equation. (1)[WKWP01]=WTT·[TKTP01] where WK and WP denote the orientation and position vectors of the cutting tool in WCS, respectively, while TK and TP the orientation and position vectors in TCS.
The complete kinematic chain from TCS to WCS exists by passing through all the coordinates of the kinematic components, that is (2)WTT=WMT·MTT=CWT-1·ACT-1·MAT-1·MYT ·YXT·XZT·ZTT

Affected by geometric and thermal errors, inevitable deviation exists between the real and ideal positions of the cutter point in WCS. The first three terms of the fourth row in HTM represent the position coordinates, so the position vector WΔP=[WΔxWΔyWΔz1]T can be written as (3)[WΔP1]=WTTr[0001]-WTT[0001] where WTTr is the transformation matrix of TCS with respect to WCS in real machines, while WTT can be obtained by neglecting all errors in ideal machines.
In this study, the tool axial vector is parallel with Z-axis, so the initial orientation vector is [0010]T. Therefore, orientation error vector WΔK can be written as (4)[WΔK0]=WTTr[0010]-WTT[0010]

Along the path from TCS to WCS, there exist 37 error components caused by five feed axes. All the errors are listed in Table 1. Note that some are purely geometric or thermal errors, while some are composed of both geometric and thermal terms. The symbol δ indicates a linear error and θ an angular error. The first subscript denotes the moving axis and the second one the direction of the error vector; x, y, z, a, and c are the nominal position coordinates of feed axes. T is the temperature vector composed of different temperature variables. All the temperature sensor locations are illustrated in Figure 1(b) and Table 2. Sxy denotes the squareness error between the X- and Y-axes. Paz denotes the parallelism error between A-axis and XOY plane. Other error components in Table 1 are represented in the same manner. Table 1.
Categories of 37 error components on a five-axis machine tool.
X-axis Y-axis Z-axis A-axis C-axis
Errors composed of geometric and thermal terms δxx(x, Tx) – F δxy(x, Tx) – F δxz(x, Tx) – F θxx(x, Tx) – R θxy(x, Tx) – F θxz(x, Tx) – F δyx(y, Ty) – F δyy(y, Ty) – F δyz(y, Ty) – F θyx(y, Ty) – F θyy(y, Ty) – R θyz(y, Ty) – F δzx(z, Tz) – F δzy(z, Tz) – F δzz(z, Tz) – F θzx(z, Tz) – F θzy(z, Tz) – F θzz(z, Tz) – R θax(a, Ta) – R θcz(c, Tc) – N
Thermal errors δax(Ta) – N δay(Ta) – N δaz(Ta) – N θay(Ta) – R θaz(Ta) – R δcx(Tc) – N δcy(Tc) – N δcz(Tc) – F θcx(Tc) – R θcy(Tc) – R
Geometric errors Sxy – F Syz – F Szx – F Paz – F Pay – F Pcx – F Pcy – F
F, functional errors; N, negligible errors; and R, random errors.
Table 2.
Temperature sensor locations.
Temperature variables Temperature sensor locations
tamb Ambient air
tmb Machine bed
txb1, txb2 The front and rear bearings on the X-axis’ ball-screw
tyb1, tyb2, tyb3, tyb4 The front and rear bearings on the Y-axis’ ball-screw
tzb1, tzb2 The front and rear bearings on the Z-axis’ ball-screw
tab1, tab2 The front and rear bearings on the A-axis’ ball-screw
tcb The bearing on the C-axis’ ball-screw
ts The spindle’s housing

Volumetric error can be calculated through equations (3) and (4). Both of them are expressed in WCS. It is, nevertheless, necessary to return to MCS to drive feed axes to conduct error compensation. As the relationship between WCS and MCS is not linear, the compensation values for each axis cannot be determined directly from equations (3) and (4). Therefore, this study proposes a compensation strategy that can compensate for both translational and rotary axes.

An example of how the compensation value is added to the X-axis motion in MCS is shown below. The ideal, uncompensated, and compensated HTMs of X-axis motion are denoted by YXT, YXTr, and YXTcomp, respectively. (5)YXT=[100axy+x010bxy001cxy0001] (6)YXTr=YXE·YXT=[1-θxz(x,Tx)θxy(x,Tx)axy+x+δxx(x,Tx)θxz(x,Tx)1-θxx(x,Tx)bxy+δxy(x,Tx)-x·Sxy-θxy(x,Tx)θxx(x,Tx)1cxy+δxz(x,Tx)0001] (7)YXTcomp=YXC·YXTr=[1-θxz(x,Tx)θxy(x,Tx)axy+x+δxx(x,Tx)+xcompθxz(x,Tx)1-θxx(x,Tx)bxy+δxy(x,Tx)-x·Sxy-θxy(x,Tx)θxx(x,Tx)1cxy+δxz(x,Tx)0001] where YXE is the error matrix caused by X-axis with respect to Y-axis, YXC the compensation matrix, (axy, bxy, cxy) the initial origin shift coordinate of XCS with respect to YCS, and xcomp the compensation value added to X-axis motion in MCS.

In the same way, the other four feed axes can be added with compensation values. Substituting all the compensated HTMs into equation (2) and making WΔP=0 in equation (3), we can obtain the compensation values of translational axes as follows. (8)WTTcomp[0001]=WTT[0001]
Also, we can get the compensation values of the rotary axes by solving the following equation. (9)WTTcomp[0010]=WTT[0010]

Solving equations (8) and (9) will produce too large a matrix to be included here. Note that the prerequisite of determination of the compensation values is to quantify all the 37 error components given in Table 1. However, this is a tough task which is time-consuming, maybe lasting for several days, and even has the characteristic of random uncertainty.20 This article proposes a simplifying method for the synthesized model and some methods for functional error components modeling in the following section.

sec.title: Modeling for geometric and thermal error components
sec.p:
As depicted in ‘Synthesized volumetric error modeling with HTM method’ section, the relationship between volumetric error and error components existing in the kinematic chain is established. As long as the error components are obtained by different measuring methods (such as laser interferometer, electronic level, autocollimator, double ball bar, etc.21,22), volumetric error can be calculated with the above synthesized error model. Researches during the past years and the measurement results show that different kinds of error components have different distribution characteristics. As demonstrated in Table 1, some errors, categorized as functional errors (including constant error components, such as Sxy, Paz, etc.), can be modeled with a function of position coordinate or temperature. Some, categorized as random errors, have the characteristics of random distribution within a certain range. The others are too small to affect machining accuracy and so they can be categorized as negligible errors. From the perspective of establishing the error compensation model, we should just focus on the functional error components which have significant influence on machining accuracy, without considering the random and negligible errors. For instance, Figure 3 shows the rolling error of X-axis under three different temperature conditions. Here, ‘Measured @ Tx1’ stands for measured curve at temperature Tx1. Obviously, they all distribute within a certain range randomly. If this kind of random error were included in the synthesized model, the accuracy of the error compensation would not be improved, and the uncertainty of the model may increase on the contrary. Figure 4 shows the angular positioning error of C-axis. Its value increases with the rise in temperature. However, it is still relatively small enough to be neglected in the synthesized model compared with the other angular errors, such as angular error around Y-axis of X-axis, as shown in Figure 9. Figure 3.
Random angular error around X-axis.
Figure 4.
Negligible angular positioning error of C-axis.

Therefore, 23 functional errors out of the 37 errors are included in the synthesized error model. This kind of error processing algorithm can not only greatly simplify the synthesized model but also reduce the random uncertainty of the volumetric error and improve the computation speed so as to meet the demand of real-time compensation in the machining process. The following discussion focuses on some typical modeling methods for functional errors.

sec.title: Modeling for positioning errors of translational axes
sec.p:
The most significant factors affecting the five-axis machine tool accuracy are translational axes’ positioning errors, which account for 50–70% of the total machine tool errors. So, it is necessary to measure and compensate for the positioning errors in order to improve the machining accuracy. As investigated in literature,2,23 positioning errors are affected by both geometric and thermal factors. Figure 5(a) shows X-axis’ positioning errors varying with position and temperature. As shown in Figure 5, ‘M@Tx1’ is the short form for ‘Measured @ Tx1’ denoting the measured curve at temperature Tx1, and ‘F@Tx1’ is the short form for ‘Fitted @ Tx1’ denoting the fitted curve at Tx1. Note the near linear variation in error with position and the slope changing with temperature. Some key heat sources affecting the positioning errors should be measured to get the temperature data for error modeling. For instance, X-axis’ positioning error is affected by not only the position coordinate, but also the temperature of the bearings on the ball-screw and the ambient air. Therefore, the error model can be divided into geometric and thermal terms, as expressed in equation (10). (10)δxx(x,Tx)=EG(x)+ET(Tx) each term is defined as follows (11)EG(x)=∑i=0nai·xi=a0+a1·x+a2·x2 +…+an·xn (12)ET(Tx)=kT·x where n denotes the degree of geometric term polynomial, x the nominal position of X-axis, and kT the temperature coefficient related to the temperature vector Tx. Due to the symmetry of the machine structure and temperature distribution, it can be found from the measurement results that the temperature of the front bearing is nearly the same as that of the rear bearing, i.e. txb1=txb2. So we can choose only Δtxb1 and the ambient temperature variation Δtamb to constitute the temperature Tx, i.e. Tx=[Δtamb,Δtxb1]T. In accordance with ISO, all dimensional measurements shall be made when the measuring instruments and the measured objects are in equilibrium with the environment, with the standard temperature maintained at 20℃. Therefore, Δtamb is the difference between tamb and the standard temperature and Δtxb1 the difference between txb1 and tamb, shown as follows (13)Δtamb=tamb-20Δtxb1=txb1-tamb Figure 5.
Positioning errors of translational axes at different temperatures: (a) X-axis; (b) Y-axis; and (c) Z-axis.

Through the analysis of the measurement data sets, we find that kT is nearly in proportion to Δtamb, while its relation with Δtxb1 is of an exponential rise rule. As is shown in Figure 6(a), the measurement was conducted when Δtamb=0∘C. The slope of kT is large and positive initially and then it decreases gradually to a steady state. Figure 6(b) shows the relation between kT and Δtxb1 when Δtamb varies from 0℃ to 6℃. All the curves in Figure 6(a) and (b) represent the same characteristics. The exponential rise is due to the fact that the heat transfer rate is related to the temperature difference between the warmer and cooler objects. The larger the temperature difference is, the higher the heat transfer rate is. Therefore, as the temperature of the bearing rises constantly, Δtxb1 is getting larger, which leads to the higher heat transfer rate from the bearing to the ambient air, and consequently, the thermal deformation rate is lowering gradually to a steady state. So kT can be determined by equation (14). (14)kT=kamb·Δtamb+kss+(k0-kss)·e-Δtxb1/τ Figure 6.
Temperature coefficient with temperature variations in X-axis.

Therefore, equation (10) can be expanded as follows. (15)δxx(x,Tx)=∑i=0nai·xi+[kamb·Δtamb+kss +(k0-kss)·e-Δtxb1/τ ]·x where kamb is the coefficient of Δtamb, k0 the initial state of Δtxb1, kss the steady state of Δtxb1, and τ the constant.

Figure 5(a) also shows the fitted curves under three different temperature conditions. The positioning errors were measured every 50 mm in the whole stroke of 600 mm. Measurement and fitted curves at Tx1 correspond to the initial state of the positioning error of X-axis. After several minutes’ motion, the temperature of the machine tool rises, and then measurement and fitted curves at Tx2 can be obtained. In the same way, curves at Tx3 can also be obtained. It can be seen obviously that each error curve varies little in shape but the slope differs under different temperature conditions. Positioning errors of Y- and Z-axes can be obtained as shown in Figure 5(b) and (c), respectively.

sec.title: Modeling for straightness and angular errors of translational axes
sec.p: Compared with positioning errors, it is more complicated to establish the error model for straightness and angular errors of translational axes. Due to different kinds of mechanical structures (guideway support structure, preload adjustment, etc.) and various temperature field distributions, straightness and angular errors show different characteristics. Two main kinds of bending shape of the guideway will be discussed in the following sections.

sec.title: Case 1: Downbent guideway
sec.p:
The guideway of X-axis is supported by both ends and takes the big weight of itself and the spindle. Therefore, it bends down in the middle and takes on the shape of nearly a quadratic curve. Generally speaking, both the above weights remain almost unchanged after assembling of the machine tool. However, much heat produced by the machining process exerts influence on the bent tendency due to the nature of thermal expansion and cold shrinkage. Through analysis of measurement data sets, we find that height h is proportional to temperature, as illustrated in Figure 7. So h(Tx) can be expressed as follows. (16)h(Tx)=∑i=1Nki·ti+p where Tx has the same meaning as in equation (10). Term ki is the coefficient of temperature ti, and p a constant. Figure 7.
Downbent guideway of X-axis.

The bend of X-axis guideway gives rise to the straightness error in the Z-axis direction. Straightness errors under different temperature conditions were measured by a laser interferometer. The measurement results at three different temperatures are shown in Figure 8. Each error curve can be fitted by a quadratic polynomial. (17)δxz(x,T)=a·x2+b·x+c Figure 8.
Straightness error of X-axis in Z-axis direction.

As illustrated in Figure 7, both ends nearly remain fixed during the motion; so, the quadratic curve goes through the points O(0, 0) and P(L, 0). Substituting the coordinates of both the points into equation (17), we can obtain the following equation. (18)δxz(x,T)=a·x2-a·L·x

Substituting the coordinate of point Q(L/2, h(Tx)) into equation (18), we can determine the unknown a. Therefore, this straightness error model can be defined as follows. (19)δxz(x,Tx)=-4(∑i=1Nki·ti+p)L2·x2 +4(∑i=1nki·ti+p)L·x where δxz(x, Tx) is a function of both coordinate x and temperature vector Tx.
Figure 8 also illustrates the fitted curves at three different temperatures. It also shows a satisfactory fitting precision.

The bend of X-axis guideway also brings about the angular error around Y-axis. It can be seen in Figure 7 that θxy(x, Tx) and δxz(x, Tx) have the differential relation, which is consistent with the conclusion in Lai’s24 research. (20)θxy(x,Tx)=-dδxz(x,Tx)dx
Therefore, θxy (x, Tx) can be formulated as follows. (21)θxy(x,Tx)=8(∑i=0Nki·ti+p)L2·x-4(∑i=0Nki·ti+p)L

Figure 9 shows the output curves of the error model at different temperatures. It shows that the maximal absolute value of the angular error can reach 0.15 × 10−3 rad, that is to say, nearly 31″. This angular error will contribute a large part of the orientation error in WCS, so it should be compensated in the machining process.

sec.title: Case 2: Rear end-up guideway
sec.p:
The rear end of Y-axis guideway is adjacent to the motor driving box and the electrical control cabinet of the machine tool. So it generates much more heat than the front end of the guideway, which leads to the thermal deformation illustrated in Figure 10. The straightness error in Z-axis direction, δz(y, Ty), can be divided into two terms, i.e. geometric and thermal. The former can be expressed by a quadratic polynomial function of Y-axis position coordinate y while the latter by a multiple linear regression function of temperatures at key heat sources Ty. The complete model of straightness error can be written as follows. (22)δyz(y,Ty)=EG(y)+ET(Ty)=a·y2+b·y +(∑i=1Nki·ti)·y+c where a, b, ki, and c are the parameters which can be determined by least squares method. Figure 11 shows the straightness errors of Y-axis in the Z-axis direction and the fitted curves under three different temperature conditions. Figure 9.
Angular error around Y-axis of X-axis.
Figure 10.
Rear end-up guideway of Y-axis.
Figure 11.
Straightness error of Y-axis in Z-axis direction.

Through the differential operation of the position y in equation (22), the angular error θyx(y, Ty) can be obtained. Also, the output curves at different temperatures are shown in Figure 12. (23)θyx(y,Ty)=dδz(y,Ty)dy=2a·y+∑i=1Nki·ti+b Figure 12.
Angular error around X-axis of Y-axis.

Experiment results indicate that six-degree-of-freedom error components of the rotary axes except angular positioning error are affected by the temperature deviations, see Table 1. Also, only δcz is the functional error which needs to be included in the volumetric error model. It can be modeled by multiple linear regression method as depicted above, without getting into computational details in this article.

sec.title: Compensation implementation and model verification
sec.p:
Another key technology in the error compensation system is to find a proper method to add compensation values obtained from the volumetric error model to the motion of the feed axes. Considering the openness of Fanuc CNC (computer numerical control) system, this study proposes a implementation technique based on the function of external machine zero point shift (EMZPS) which is included in some types of Fanuc CNC systems, such as Series 0i, 16i, 18i, 30i, etc. This function can be employed in our developed system to compensate for all the five axes simultaneously. Compensation values obtained from error compensation software are stored in R address in programmable machine controller (PMC). CNC system can read these data within a cyclical scan cycle, that is to say, compensation values can be added to the feed axes controller within around 8 ms (one PMC scan cycle). In addition, the software and CNC system is connected through the Ethernet cable under the Fanuc Open CNC API Specifications protocol. Mature Ethernet data transmission technology can insure the stable transmission of data without electromagnetic interference under complicated production environments. The flowchart of volumetric error compensation strategy and the data exchanging method is illustrated in Figure 13. Figure 13.
Flowchart of volumetric error compensation strategy.
HTM: homogeneous transformation matrix; FOCAS: Fanuc Open CNC API Specifications; EMZPS: external machine zero point shift; and CNC: computer numerical control.

To verify the feasibility of the volumetric error compensation system, some experiments were conducted on a vertical five-axis machine tool which used Fanuc 18i as its numerical control system. The overall experimental procedure is listed as follows:
All the backlash errors of five axes were compensated beforehand.
Measurements were performed to quantify the error components presented in Table 1. The translational errors, such as positioning and straightness errors, were measured by Renishaw laser interferometer. Some angular errors were measured by electronic levels. Also, the temperature data were collected by the thermistor PT100 in association with the data acquisition board Adam-6015 featured by open wiring diagnostic and Ethernet data transmission function. All the functional error components were selected to establish the synthesized model, and all the parameters in the geometric and thermal error models for each axis were determined.
Orientation and position compensation values were obtained with synthesized volumetric error model.
According to the standard,25 laser diagonal measurement was conducted to estimate the volumetric accuracy of the machine tool. As shown in Figure 14, measuring paths are along four diagonals which are represented as follows: PPP – from (0, 0, 0) to (600, 550, 450), NPP – from (600, 0, 0) to (0, 550, 450), PNP – from (0, 550, 0) to (600, 0, 450), and PPN – from (0, 0, 450) to (600, 550, 0). Here, P indicates the positive direction of translational axis and N the negative direction. Twenty target positions are chosen for each diagonal respectively. To verify the effectiveness of the volumetric error model under different temperature conditions, measurements were both conducted at the initial state and after running of the machine tool for 1 h. Comparing Figures 15 and 16, it can be seen clearly that thermal errors cause the degradation of the volumetric accuracy performance. Also, volumetric error compensation can improve the accuracy at least by 38%. Measurement results are detailed in Table 3.
Table 3.
Laser diagonal measurement results with and without volumetric error compensation.
Compensation status Minimum (µm) Maximum (µm) Mean (µm) Range (µm) Improved by (%)
PPP Initial state Without compensation 0 45 31 45 62
With compensation 0 17 12 17
Running for 1 hour Without compensation 0 70 35 70 41
With compensation −15 27 6 41
NPP Initial state Without compensation 0 26 16 26 50
With compensation 0 13 7 13
Running for 1 h Without compensation 0 42 26 42 50
With compensation 0 21 14 21
PNP Initial state Without compensation −14 0 −9 14 50
With compensation −6 1 −3 7
Running for 1 h Without compensation −32 0 22 32 38
With compensation −15 5 6 20
PPN Initial state Without compensation −32 4 −21 36 64
With compensation −7 6 2 13
Running for 1 h Without compensation −53 0 32 53 71
With compensation −13 2 −6 15
Figure 16.
Comparison of diagonal displacement accuracy with and without volumetric error compensation after running of the machine tool for 1 h: (a) PPP; (b) NPP; (c) PNP; and (d) PPN.
Figure 15.
Comparison of diagonal displacement accuracy with and without volumetric error. Compensation at the initial state of the machine tool: (a) PPP; (b) NPP; (c) PNP; and (d) PPN.
Figure 14.
Measuring paths along four diagonals in the working volume.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
This article proposes a synthesized volumetric error compensation model which can compensate for both geometric and thermal errors on five-axis machine tools. Orientation and position errors can be obtained from the volumetric error model. Some typical modeling methods are discussed in this study. Also, laser diagonal measurements show that the compensation system can improve the volumetric accuracy effectively. The following conclusions can be drawn:
Positioning errors of translational axes are composed of geometric and thermal terms. The geometric term can be modeled by a polynomial of the position coordinate. Due to the fact that the machine tool thermal deformation process is a typical non-linear system, an exponential growth modeling method is proposed to establish the relationship between the temperature variables and the coefficient in the thermal term.
The models of straightness errors in each axis depend on the mechanical structure and the heat source distribution. Therefore, two main types of modeling method with high fitted accuracy are presented in this article.
Compensation implementation technique based on EMZPS function and Ethernet data communication protocol is applied to transmit the error compensation values to the CNC system. This technique is featured by high data transmission speed, low interference of electromagnetism, and great stability of compensation process under complicated working conditions.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was funded by the Chinese National Science and Technology Key Special Projects [grant no: 2011ZX04015-031] and the National Science Foundation Project of P.R. China [grant no: 51175343].

BryanJ. International status of thermal error research. CIRP Ann Manuf Technol 1990; 39: 645–656.
TsutsumiMSaitoA. Identification and compensation of systematic deviations particular to 5-axis machining centers. Int J Mach Tools Manuf 2003; 43: 771–780.
ISO230-1:1996. Test code for machine tools. Part 1: Geometric accuracy of machines operating under no-load or finishing conditiongs. International Standards Organization.
SuhSHLeeESJungSY. Error modelling and measurement for the rotary table of five-axis machine tools. Int J Adv Manuf Technol 1998; 14: 656–663.
